channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How the West Marshaled a Stunning Show of Unity Against Russia
item.description: In a few frantic days, the West threw out the playbook it used for decades against the Kremlin and isolated Russia with unparalleled sanctions and penalties.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Katrin Bennhold and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Friday in Mykolayiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Live Updates: Putin Threatens to Strip Ukraine of Statehood, as Russian Advance Slows
item.description: The Russian leader escalated his threats as Ukrainian forces continued to resist. Protests broke out in the first major city captured by Russia. A limited cease-fire collapsed in a besieged city. Israel’s prime minister visits Moscow.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of a Ukrainian military unit at a barricade in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Saturday.

item.title: Israel PM Naftali Bennett Visits Moscow for Putin Talks on Ukraine
item.description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel met for three hours with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the Israeli leader’s office said.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naftali Bennett, Israel’s Prime Minister, met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Russia on Saturday.

item.title: A Welcome Steeped in History: Ukrainian Refugees Arrive in Germany
item.description: Berlin has become a major hub for refugees from Ukraine, welcoming them with an outpouring of help. The response stirs memories of both bright and dark chapters of German history.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Greeting a passenger arriving on a train from Poland in Berlin on Wednesday.

item.title: China Outlines Plan to Stabilize Economy in Crucial Year for Xi
item.description: China calls for heavy government spending and lending, as its leaders seek to project confidence in the face of global uncertainty over the pandemic and war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and Premier Li Keqiang at the opening of the National People’s Congress in Beijing on Saturday.

item.title: Build a New City or New Humans? A Utopia in India Fights Over Future.
item.description: Backed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the new leadership of Auroville, an experimental commune, wants to create a model city. In the way stand trees, tree houses and a take-it-slow tradition.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Matrimandir, a place for meditation, in Auroville, India, a spiritual commune founded in the state of Tamil Nadu in the 1960s.

item.title: In Ukraine’s West, Lviv Makes Itself a Vital Rear Base
item.description: Spared direct attacks so far, the city has become a transit point for thousands of fleeing refugees and for men and supplies headed to the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Lviv, Ukraine, on Friday evening.

item.title: What Cities Is Russia Targeting in Ukraine?
item.description: About two-thirds of Ukraine’s population of 44 million people lived in cities before Russia’s invasion began. Now many urban areas are in the cross hairs of war.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleaning up debris after a residential building was hit by missiles in Kyiv in February.

item.title: In a surrounded Ukrainian city, residents vow to fight to the end.
item.description: Wearing flak jackets and toting Kalashnikovs, many people in Mykolaiv say they are bracing to fight the advancing Russians.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: “The captain leaves the ship last,” said Oleksandr Senkevich, Mykolaiv’s mayor. The streets of the city were mostly deserted on Friday, with Ukrainian soldiers expecting a Russian attack imminently.

item.title: Ukraine War Forces a Question: How Far East Does Europe Go?
item.description: After Russia invaded, Ukraine asked to join the European Union, quickly. Moldova and Georgia have asked, too. Member states would rather not answer.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Walking past destroyed houses in the Ukrainian village of Dachne, north of Odessa, on Wednesday.

item.title: An Italian Princess From Texas Awaits Her Next Act
item.description: Princess Rita Boncompagni Ludovisi, formerly Rita Jenrette, is locked in a battle over the estate of her late husband, a Roman prince.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Princess Rita Boncampagni Ludovisi in Villa Aurora, Rome, her home for the moment.

item.title: Russian Filmmakers and Other Artists Face Boycotts Over Ukraine
item.description: A Russian moviemaker with Ukrainian roots and relatives in Kyiv denounced the war. The Glasgow Film Festival dropped his film anyway.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Russia Takes Censorship to New Extremes, Stifling War Coverage
item.description: Contradicting the Kremlin on the war in Ukraine — even calling it a war — is now a crime, prompting independent media to close, and Russia cut off access to Facebook, the BBC and other news sources.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A live broadcast in the studio of “Echo of Moscow” after the announcement that the station would shutter on Thursday.

item.title: China’s Legislative Session to Focus on Economy
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine went unmentioned at the opening of an annual gathering of China’s legislature, as leaders focused on stabilizing economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Thursday, ahead of the annual gathering of China’s legislature.

item.title: Mexico Soccer Riot Leaves 22 Injured, Querétaro Officials Say
item.description: Videos posted on social media showed violent clashes between fans in a stadium in the central city of Querétaro on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Fans of rival teams at the stadium near Querétaro, Mexico, where bloody violence broke out on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Prisoners and Ukrainian Soldiers Describe Two Sides of the Conflict
item.description: The accounts painted a picture of a conflict consisting largely of ambushes, at least in northern Ukraine where the Russian forces are striving to encircle and capture the capital, Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian sniper prepares his rifle at a base in Kyiv on Saturday, as forces prepared to battle Russian troops entering the city.

item.title: Mastercard and Visa Suspend Operations in Russia
item.description: Russian-issued cards will no longer work in other countries, and purchases from Russian vendors by cardholders in other countries will be cut off.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: People stand in line to get cash at the ATM at the shopping mall in Moscow, Russia, last month.

item.title: US Officials Travel to Venezuela, a Russia Ally, as the West Isolates Putin
item.description: The trip is the highest-level visit by American officials to Caracas in years, driven by a desire to separate Russia from its remaining Latin American allies.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Natalie Kitroeff and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, right, with Yuri Borisov, the deputy prime minister of Russia, in Caracas, Venezuela, in mid-February.

item.title: Fast-Food Chains Stay Open in Russia, Mostly Quiet About Ukraine
item.description: Many fast-food chains are facing growing pressure on social media platforms and from large investors to halt operations in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:description: McDonald’s and other fast-food chains have continued to operate in Russia even as other companies reduced their presence there.

item.title: Does Part of Putin's Wartime Mindset Reflect Pandemic Isolation?
item.description: Analysts are debating whether the Russian leader’s ambitions and appetite for risk have been altered by his long-held Covid bubble, or by his urgency to secure a legacy, or both.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia stayed at physical distance from his national security advisers at a meeting at the Kremlin on Feb. 21, days before Russia’s forces invaded Ukraine.

item.title: Putin Likens Sanctions to a ‘Declaration of War’
item.description: Despite a cease-fire, Russia shelled near humanitarian corridors meant for civilians to escape an embattled city, Ukraine says, while the Russian leader also warned about a no-fly zone.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Ukrainians fleeing Kyiv sheltered under a destroyed bridge while waiting to cross the Irpin River on the outskirts of the city on Saturday.

item.title: Pakistan Identifies Peshawar Suicide Bomber and Network, Police Say
item.description: The attack at a Shiite mosque, claimed by an ISIS affiliate, killed at least 63 people and left nearly 200 wounded.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Khan and Salman Masood
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A funeral on Saturday for some of the people killed on Friday in a bomb blast at a mosque in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: Ukrainian Protesters Take to the Streets in Occupied Kherson
item.description: Kherson was the first major city to fall to Russian forces and the protests are presenting a challenge to the new authority.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora, Evan Hill and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Allies Focus on Security of Zelensky and Other Ukraine Leaders
item.description: Concerns about the line of succession were prompted in part because President Volodymyr Zelensky insists he will not be evacuated.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine held a news conference on Thursday at an undisclosed location.

item.title: Aeroflot, Russia's State Airline, Says it Will Suspend International Flights
item.description: Russia’s airline industry has been hit hard as countries around the world have imposed sanctions on the country for its invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Aeroflot aircraft at the Sheremetyevo airport in Moscow, on Monday.

item.title: True Stories
item.description: Why are so many drama series based on real-life events?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: While Canada Welcomes Refugees, Its Door Is Far From Wide Open
item.description: The war in Ukraine may bring another wave of asylum seekers to Canada, but they will face many controls and restrictions.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A train full of passengers coming from Kyiv arrived at the train station in Lviv, Ukraine, on Friday. Many of them will continue west.

item.title: TikTok Ukraine War Videos Raise Questions About Spread of Misinformation
item.description: The Chinese-owned video app is dealing with a flood of war videos and the question of whether it is spreading unverified information.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian security forces guard Maidan Square in Kyiv as Russian forces fought on the outskirts of the city on Wednesday. Many videos purporting to be of the war have flooded TikTok.

item.title: The Best Time to Use Your Airline Points and Miles
item.description: If you’re thinking of traveling and you’ve got points or miles sitting in airline and credit card accounts, the time to cash in may have arrived. Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed

item.title: Too Close to Putin? Institutions Vet Artists, Uncomfortably.
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has led arts organizations to reconsider who performs, forcing them to confront questions about free speech and policing political views.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko (with Mariusz Kwiecien) appearing in “Eugene Onegin” at the Metropolitan Opera in 2013. She and the Met parted ways this week after she declined to denounce President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Gov. Murphy Ends Virus Briefings in New Jersey and Tries to Turn Page
item.description: Friday’s briefing was two years to the day since the state’s first confirmed coronavirus case, the governor said, and served as a fitting end to his pandemic updates.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey in Trenton last month. He had imposed some of the nation’s strictest coronavirus restrictions during the pandemic.

item.title: Finland, Non-NATO and Nervous, Discusses Defense With Biden
item.description: “We usually don’t start wars,” President Sauli Niinisto of Finland said as the leaders spoke amid the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The public conversation on Friday between President Biden and President Sauli Niinisto of Finland did not mention NATO membership.

item.title: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile, South Korea Says
item.description: The launch is North Korea’s second missile test in a week and comes only days before the presidential election in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage in Seoul of a North Korean missile launch last week.

item.title: Zelensky Criticizes NATO Over Its Rejection of a No-fly Zone Over Ukraine
item.description: “All the people who will die from this day will die because of you, as well,” the Ukrainian president told NATO leaders in a video shared on social media.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women and children line up to buy tickets and board trains in Lviv on Friday.

item.title: Russia Seizes Nuclear Plant in Ukraine and Makes Gain in the South
item.description: The Russian military advance in Ukraine sowed more destruction and chaos, pointing to a worsening conflict, as the Kremlin also moved to restrict how it’s reported at home.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families in Kyiv waited for a train west on Friday.

item.title: A.C.L.U. Lawsuit Accuses ICE Jailers of Denying Detainees Vaccines
item.description: One of the plaintiffs is Anna Sorokin, a Russian immigrant who for several years presented herself as a German heiress named Anna Delvey. She received a booster shot on Thursday, two days after the suit was filed.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Sorokin, one of the four named plaintiffs in a suit filed this week by the A.C.L.U., had made several requests for a booster shot. She received one two days after the suit was filed.

item.title: In Kyiv’s Railway Station, Rumors, Near-Stampedes and Frustration
item.description: As Russian forces begin to encircle the Ukrainian capital, tens of thousands are clambering for a way out that may soon be closed off.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: As rumors flew of the arrival of a train headed from Kyiv to western Ukraine, hundreds of people scrambled across the tracks, hoping to get to the platform first.

item.title: FDA Rejects India-Made Bharat Biotech Vaccine For Those Under 18
item.description: The vaccine, made by Bharat Biotech, is widely used in India. It has not been tested in the U.S., which has not authorized it for any age groups.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: A health worker preparing a shot of Covaxin Covid vaccine developed by Bharat Biotech at the vaccination center in New Delhi, last year.

item.title: As Russia Pounds Ukraine, NATO Countries Rush In Javelins and Stingers
item.description: The American weapons are part of a $350 million package that President Biden authorized on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces in Kharkhiv, the country’s second-largest city, on Friday.

item.title: Anti-Covid-Vaccine Doctor Pleads Guilty to Capitol Riot Charges
item.description: The founder of America’s Frontline Doctors, a group that spreads pandemic misinformation, stood by as a Capitol Police officer was assaulted, then entered the Capitol and made a speech against Covid vaccines, according to a Justice Department filing.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: John Clanton/Tulsa World, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Simone Gold, founder of the anti-Covid-vaccine group America’s Frontline Doctors, speaking at an event in Jenks, Okla., last June.

item.title: NATO Accuses Russia of Using Cluster Bombs in Ukraine
item.description: Officials made the accusation Friday as part of a display of a unified front in support of Ukraine, but rejected a plea from Kyiv to impose a no-fly zone over its airspace.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: NATO foreign ministers during a meeting in Brussels on Friday to discuss the response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the growing refugee crisis in Europe.

item.title: Russia Blocks Facebook, as Kremlin Moves to Stifle Dissent
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: A woman checking her phone on the Moscow subway in 2020. Facebook was not as popular as YouTube or Telegram in Russia, but was a platform where people could find news outside state-run outlets.

item.title: The War in Ukraine Holds a Warning for the World Order
item.description: The multinational response shows that liberalism has some life left. But the challenges posed by waning U.S. power and rising authoritarianism remain formidable.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maidan square in central Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: With Sanctions, U.S. and Europe Aim to Punish Putin and Fuel Russian Unrest
item.description: The Biden administration and European officials are crushing the Russian economy and stirring mass anxiety to pressure President Vladimir V. Putin to end his war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: A shop in Moscow on Monday displayed the plunging exchange rate for the ruble.

item.title: An appeals ruling bars the U.S. from expelling any endangered migrant families on public health grounds.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:description: Migrants expelled from the United States under Title 42, walking towards Mexico at the Paso del Norte International border bridge last October.

item.title: BBC Suspends Operations in Russia After Censorship Law Is Passed
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu

item.title: ‘We Have No Choice’: Mothers in Ukraine Flee to Poland
item.description: At a station in Western Ukraine, mothers and their children boarded evacuation trains to Poland, while many of their husbands stayed to defend the country from advancing Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey and Mark Boyer
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for The New York Times

item.title: Monique Hanotte, Savior of Allied Airmen, Dies at 101
item.description: Using her knowledge of the Belgium-France border and quick thinking, she guided dozens of downed Allied airmen to safety during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Monique Hanotte in 2020. She was one of the last surviving members of the Comet line, a Belgian Resistance operation.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War Helped Ease Rift Between Britain and the E.U.
item.description: The crisis in Ukraine is beginning to narrow the chasm opened up by Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s foreign secretary, arriving for a meeting with her European Union counterparts in Brussels on Friday. The meeting underscores a striking rapprochement.

item.title: Lindsey Graham Says of Putin: Someone in Russia Should ‘Take This Guy Out’
item.description: The comments drew sharp rebukes from other Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: NATO Rejects Intervening in Ukraine, Including No-Fly Zone
item.description: The alliance will not engage Russian forces in the air or on the ground in Ukraine to avoid the risk of a wider European war, the secretary-general says.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: NATO foreign ministers Friday in Brussels during a meeting on the response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the growing refugee situation in Europe.

item.title: Tesla Wins Approval to Open European Assembly Plant
item.description: German authorities cleared the plant, which was built near Berlin, to open for production. Tesla plans to build 500,000 electric cars a year there.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Andreas Meichsner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tesla’s Gigafactory Berlin-Brandenburg.

item.title: ISIS Claims Bombing of Pakistani Mosque, Killing Dozens
item.description: More than 50 people were killed and more than 100 wounded after an explosion tore through a Shiite mosque in one of the worst terrorist attacks in Pakistan in years.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Khan and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Security officials at the site of an attack on a Shiite mosque on Friday in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: Russia’s Brutal Advance
item.description: It’s creating a humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers cross a destroyed bridge.

item.title: Fire at Ukraine Nuclear Plant Is Out, but Russian Troops Take Control
item.description: International observers and Ukrainian officials said that as of 6 a.m. the facility was still able to function safely.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and William J. Broad
item.media:description: A damaged administrative building of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Enerhodar, Ukraine, in a handout picture released on Friday.

item.title: Catch up on the latest news on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Here's What to Read About the Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: Our reporters have been covering the crisis, from documenting military movement and the refugee exodus on the ground to analyzing global geopolitical developments.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The village of Dachne, just north of Odessa, Ukraine.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russia gains ground in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An evacuation train headed toward Lviv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: After Fire, Russian Troops Seize Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant
item.description: Security camera footage showed a building ablaze inside the complex amid fighting. The fire was later extinguished. A Ukrainian agency said that Russian forces had taken control of the site.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, William J. Broad, Malachy Browne, Brenna Smith and Ang Li

item.title: Video: How Melitopol Is Coping With Presence of Russian Troops
item.description: ​​Videos verified by The New York Times show some residents of Melitopol meeting Russian troops with a mix of anger and scorn, and others lining up for aid in a central square.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill and Dmitriy Khavin
